solution_03_central_limit_theorem/03_central_limit_theorem/14_binom_between_v1

video

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. \[\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (196)(0.9) ~=~ 176.4\] \[\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(196)(0.9)(0.1)} ~=~ 4.2 \]

We determine both \(z\)-scores. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used \(\sum x\) to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use \(x\) as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) We get the first \(z\)-score.

\[\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{x_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{173.5-176.4}{4.2} \\\\ &= -0.6904762 \end{aligned}\]

We get the second \(z\)-score.

\[\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{x_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{175.5-176.4}{4.2} \\\\ &= -0.2142857 \end{aligned}\]

Then, find the standard normal probability.

\[P(-0.6904762 < Z < -0.2142857) ~=~ 0.1702147 \]

Of course, you could have rounded the \(z\)-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. \[P(-0.7 < Z < -0.22) ~=~ 0.1709 \] \[P(-0.69 < Z < -0.21) ~=~ 0.1717 \] \[P(-0.7 < Z < -0.21) ~=~ 0.1678 \] \[P(-0.69 < Z < -0.22) ~=~ 0.1748 \]
